Dossiers

The Hybrid Publishing Consortium’s Dossiers are composed of a selection and arrangement of 500-2000 words working papers/reports, plus an introduction explaining the composition of the dossier and the articulation between its different parts (reports). The reports can be commissioned texts as well as pre-existing ones, they are multi-format: lists, essays, notes, slide shows, etc.

In order to be able to publish a report in several Dossiers, the system for editing/organizing/archiving the reports need to be flexible.

The reports will be stored in a GitHub repository, each one in a folder composed of the content in an html file, a folder for images and other documents, and a css file (when neccessary).

Diagram

Single source, yet medium specific

To tune parts of the reports in relation with a specific medium (for instance only for print), we can use specific class names (convention needed for that) that will then be displayed or not depending on the format.

HTML style guide

If we want ePub-ready files, we should write in a compatible way (ePub is XHTML). A solution for that is Polyglot Markup. We could also run a validator (with HTML5 Validator, that can be run with Travis CI), which validates the code that is pushed on GitHub. And use transpect to convert HTML5 to XHTML.

Hybrid design

The HPC documentation and publications’ design is inspired by the following notions: multi-format, hybridity, flexibility, multiplicity, transformation. It consists of a design system, a series of guidelines, responsive and media-specific CSS styles, and a set of Free and Open source materials and tools, that can be modified to fit with specific uses. In a Free and Open Source spirit, it promotes a wide, free and shared distribution of knowledge. It is thus taking into account both accessible and high-costs formats, big and small screens, PDFs for A4 personal printer as well as Offset-ready files…

Structure of the body of the html file


    <header>
        <img class="logo img-responsive" src="static/hpc-logoxx.png" alt="hpc-logo">
    </header>
    
    <div id="main">
        <div class="page-title">
            <div class="more slide_up">
                <h1>TITLE</h1>
                <p>MORE</p>
            </div>
            <section id="header_slide">
                <div class="strapline">
                    <p></p>
                 </div>
             </section>
        </div> <!-- end div page-title -->
        
        <section>
            <h2></h2>
            <p></p>  
            <figure>
                <img>
                <figcaption>Fig1.</figcaption>
            </figure> 
        </section>
        
    </div> <!-- end div main -->
    
    <footer>
        <div class="contact slide_up">
            <p></p> 
            <div class="footer-logos">
                <img> <img> <img>
            </div>
        </div>
        <section id="footer_slide"><p></p>
            <p></p>
        </section>
    </footer>

Free and Open Source fonts

  • REGLO, a font by OSP Foundry, designed by Sebastien Sanfilippo to be streched. OFL
  • REGLO
  • Bagnard, also designed by Sebastien Sanfilippo, quite hype, display and very bold texts (but no italics… for the moment). OFL
  • Montserrat, a font by Julieta Ulanovsky, created to keep a trace of old posters and signs in the traditional neighborhood of Buenos Aires called Montserrat. OFL
  • Cotham, a sans serif grotesk font by Sebastien Sanfilippo. OFL
  • NotCourier Sans, monospace chopped by OSP. OFL
  • Charter, a serif typeface designed by Matthew Carter for Bitstream Inc. Foundry, donated in 1992 to another Consortium, the X Consortium, under an Open Source license. The font is based on 18th century characters designed by Pierre-Simon Fournier, and was optimized for printing on low-resolution laser printers of the 1980s. The encounter between the very fine design inspired by Fournier’s characters and the low resolution of the personal printing technologies makes it a real multi-format font that is very legible on both low and high-tech screen and print. License
  • Work Sans is a “superfamily” of fonts based on early Grotesques, designed by by Wei Huang with Metapolator. Some of its 10 weights were optimised for screen medium-sized text usage (14px-48px), the thinner and heavier for display use, and they also look fine on paper. But the superfamily doesn’t have italics… yet! OFL
  • Lato is a more complete family of fonts with many weights and italics, designed by Łukasz Dziedzic. It is described as “Male and female, serious but friendly. With the feeling of the Summer”… OFL
